column4: Hey, what's the best way to remotely transfer files between Ubuntu and Windows, such as in a remote desktop situation?
you could probably set up an FTP server
What about securing the FTP server?
well it depends on how you plan to use it -- one-time bulk transfer of stuff, or regular use
with Hamachi, you're pretty safe, as they encrypt all traffic with AES-256 (or so they claim)
in other words, everything going via them should be encrypted end-to-end
there's a Linux client available
and it's not too tricky to set up
about FTP -- you could always pick a non-standard port
that's a "weak" approach, but it's a LOT better than nothing
by "weak", i mean it only adds a very minor level of security; determined intruders will be completely unphased, but it's enough to stop "dumb" bots and the like
yeah, it's surprisingly good quality software :-)
i'll be doing that shortly, once i finish setting up my desktop (and learning all the quirks)
it's like the good old days of reading manuals and actually learning (my brain is rusty after several years of mostly-windows, due to work)
try a command-line app called 'top'
in some IRC clients, the 'tab' key is used for auto-completion; a partial (ambiguous) completion usually lists the partial matches
the client i'm using right now (pidgin -- stop barfing, people, it came pre-installed, and i don't look a gift horse in the mouth) adds the colon automagically
as for photoshop, you'll find the gimp to probably be a more-than-adequate substitute, unless you are a super hardcore-user
i'm unfamiliar with lightroom (not a photographer myself)
however, you can run windows inside a window in linux
I tried earlier, but I don't know how to install them in Linux.
Titan8990 suggested a nice command-line way that should work (sudo apt-get install gimp)
you might need to do a 'sudo apt-get update' first
ah, that sounds like a useful tool, for sure (i'm a quality nut)
